Such individuals necessarily concern themselves in teaching solely with superfi¬
cial and obvious uses which grow out of an essentially amateur approach. If maximum
use of these media is to be made it is urgent that a body of information be developed
which will provide a solid foundation for such courses, not based on guesswork or
assumed transfer of common elements among the various types of media.
Serious scholars now recognize that a large proportion of the effects of television and
radio are often unintentional or unintended ones. A large part of the impact of these media
is not dependent on the content transmitted. Scholars of educational, commercial,
government-controlled, and other systems in the world, in other words, are beginning
to discover that most of the cumulative psychological and conditioning impact of televi¬
sion and radio is independent of the message communicated. In many respects, in fact,
the medium itself is the message or a large part of it.
The number of elements which characterize the effects of the use of these media as
such, regardless of their content, their message or the system under which they are
operated, illustrate the need for research in depth and experimental evaluation on the
basis of which the teaching of procedural and methodological uses.of a socially and
educationally responsible type can be soundly based. Without such a foundation, many
unintended effects and “side-effects** will continue to result, and more accidental suc¬
cesses and abuses are likely to occur than soundly-based maximum effectiveness uses.
